Award.AwardTitle: IRES: Sustainable Development of a Tropical Agroforestry Program in the Rural Borneo Highlands
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will collect baseline ecological data to record the response of a degraded tropical forest in the Bornean highlands to the introduction of an agroforestry system. The highlands were returned to indigenous (Kadazan) persons in Malaysian Borneo following two clear-cuttings over the last century; and the agroforestry system is designed to restore the forest canopy. 11 undergraduate and 2 MS students from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines will collect data in paid 8-week summer ecological field research experiences. Data include soil properties (organic matter, chemical content, pH, water holding capacity, fungi to bacteria ratio), arthropod diversity (beetles, ants and butterflies) and fructivorous and insectivorous bat communities.

The data record ecological changes at producer sites and will be compared to sites at the same elevation in an adjacent and protected national forest range for ecological benchmarking. Benchmarking serves to help qualify agroforestry practices for international green product labelling, which would substantially elevate producer incomes. Results will improve scientific understanding of the linkages among ecological communities in tropical forests from soil to canopy; and, finally, students will gain professional experience in designing ecological field experiments, collecting and analyzing data, and communicating results to stakeholders from different cultures and academics at professional conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Results from this project highlighted that logging and forest conversion significantly affect soil microbial diversity and can have lasting effects on carbon cycling in tropical montane forests.

Intellectual Merits: This project collected baseline ecological data to record the response of degraded tropical forests in the Bornean highlands to the introduction of a sustainable agroforestry system. Data include meteorological variables, canopy structure, soil physical, chemical and biological properties at three privately owned degraded sites and three old growth forests. Overall, this project resulted in 1 MS thesis, 1 publication, and 8 conference presentations/seminars.

Broader Impacts: Data collected through this project will be used by the landowners to track the progress of the agroforestry program. One undergraduate and one graduate student from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines collected data in a paid 8-week ecological field research experience during summer 2018. Additionally, one graduate, and two undergraduate students received training on the data collected through this project. Students gained professional experience in designing ecological field experiments, collecting and analyzing data, and communicating results through conference presentations and peer reviewed publications. One postdoctoral scientist gained experience in mentoring students in international field settings and working with international stakeholders and scientists. The undergraduate student received the NSF-GRF award and joined a doctoral program in tropical ecology, the graduate student graduated and joined the workforce in the natural resource management, and the postdoctoral scientist joined a tenure-track position.
